00001 /* $Id: scanner.ll 44 2008-10-23 09:03:19Z tb $ -*- mode: c++ -*- */
00004 %{ /*** C/C++ Declarations ***/
00005 
00006 #include <string>
00007 
00008 #include "scanner.h"
00009 
00010 /* import the parser's token type into a local typedef */
00011 typedef example::Parser::token token;
00012 typedef example::Parser::token_type token_type;
00013 
00014 /* By default yylex returns int, we use token_type. Unfortunately yyterminate
00015  * by default returns 0, which is not of token_type. */
00016 #define yyterminate() return token::END
00017 
00018 /* This disables inclusion of unistd.h, which is not available under Visual C++
00019  * on Win32. The C++ scanner uses STL streams instead. */
00020 #define YY_NO_UNISTD_H
00021 
00022 %}
00023 
00024 /*** Flex Declarations and Options ***/
00025 
00026 /* enable c++ scanner class generation */
00027 %option c++
00028 
00029 /* change the name of the scanner class. results in "ExampleFlexLexer" */
00030 %option prefix="Example"
00031 
00032 /* the manual says "somewhat more optimized" */
00033 %option batch
00034 
00035 /* enable scanner to generate debug output. disable this for release
00036  * versions. */
00037 %option debug
00038 
00039 /* no support for include files is planned */
00040 %option yywrap nounput 
00041 
00042 /* enables the use of start condition stacks */
00043 %option stack
00044 
00045 /* The following paragraph suffices to track locations accurately. Each time
00046  * yylex is invoked, the begin position is moved onto the end position. */
00047 %{
00048 #define YY_USER_ACTION  yylloc->columns(yyleng);
00049 %}
00050 
00051 %% /*** Regular Expressions Part ***/
00052 
00053  /* code to place at the beginning of yylex() */
00054 %{
00055     // reset location
00056     yylloc->step();
00057 %}
00058 
00059  /*** BEGIN EXAMPLE - Change the example lexer rules below ***/
00060 
00061 [0-9]+ {
00062     yylval->integerVal = atoi(yytext);
00063     return token::INTEGER;
00064 }
00065 
00066 [0-9]+"."[0-9]* {
00067     yylval->doubleVal = atof(yytext);
00068     return token::DOUBLE;
00069 }
00070 
00071 [A-Za-z][A-Za-z0-9_,.-]* {
00072     yylval->stringVal = new std::string(yytext, yyleng);
00073     return token::STRING;
00074 }
00075 
00076  /* gobble up white-spaces */
00077 [ \t\r]+ {
00078     yylloc->step();
00079 }
00080 
00081  /* gobble up end-of-lines */
00082 \n {
00083     yylloc->lines(yyleng); yylloc->step();
00084     return token::EOL;
00085 }
00086 
00087  /* pass all other characters up to bison */
00088 . {
00089     return static_cast<token_type>(*yytext);
00090 }
00091 
00092  /*** END EXAMPLE - Change the example lexer rules above ***/
00093 
00094 %% /*** Additional Code ***/
00095

00115 /* This implementation of ExampleFlexLexer::yylex() is required to fill the
00116  * vtable of the class ExampleFlexLexer. We define the scanner's main yylex
00117  * function via YY_DECL to reside in the Scanner class instead. */
00118 
00119 #ifdef yylex
00120 #undef yylex
00121 #endif
00122 
00123 int ExampleFlexLexer::yylex()
00124 {
00125     std::cerr << "in ExampleFlexLexer::yylex() !" << std::endl;
00126     return 0;
00127 }
00128 
00129 /* When the scanner receives an end-of-file indication from YY_INPUT, it then
00130  * checks the yywrap() function. If yywrap() returns false (zero), then it is
00131  * assumed that the function has gone ahead and set up `yyin' to point to
00132  * another input file, and scanning continues. If it returns true (non-zero),
00133  * then the scanner terminates, returning 0 to its caller. */
00134 
00135 int ExampleFlexLexer::yywrap()
00136 {
00137     return 1;
00138 }
